required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Obesity-related Genes in Taiwanese Undergoing Weight Loss
clinical_study.official_title: Searching for the Most Influential Obesity-related Diabetic Genes and Exploring the Expression Profiles of Those Genes in Taiwanese Undergoing Weight Loss

brief_summary.textblock:
To investigate:
1. Associations between miRNA and insulin signaling-related gene expressions in abdominal adipose tissues in obese subjects.
2. Differences in miRNAs expressed by intrabdominal omental adipose tissues between genders.

detailed_description.textblock: Compared the differences in microRNA expressions of abdominal adipose tissue in morbid obese male and female subjects to elucidate the possible regulatory role of microRNA in insulin signaling-related gene expression levels and its association with biochemical markers. We hope to find a miRNA that can be used to predict the syndrome associated with obesity.

primary_outcome.measure: MicroRNA expression in abdominal omental adipose tissues
primary_outcome.description: MicroRNA-125a-3p expression in abdominal omental adipose tissues is associated with insulin signaling-related gene expression levels in morbid obesity

arm_group.description: Paired samples of abdominal subcutaneous and intrabdominal omental adipose tissue were obtained from men and women who underwent bariatric surgery.

intervention.description: Paired samples of abdominal subcutaneous and intrabdominal omental adipose tissue were obtained from men and women who underwent bariatric surgery.
intervention.other_name: BMI were all over 40 kg/ m2

biospec_descr.textblock: Paired samples of abdominal subcutaneous and intrabdominal omental adipose tissue were obtained from men and women who underwent laparoscopic bariatric surgery.

study_pop.textblock: Paired samples of abdominal subcutaneous and intrabdominal omental adipose tissue were obtained from men (n = 9) and women (n =10) who underwent bariatric surgery. Their BMI were all over 40 kg/ m2, and ages between 19-63 years.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Morbid obesity,BMIs> 40 kg/m2
- Subjects who underwent bariatric surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- Obese subjects with complicated metabolic disorders
- Thyroid disease

overall_official.affiliation: Comprehensive Weight Management Center Taipei Medical University Hospital

link.description: Taipei Medical University-Joint Institutional Review Board
Comprehensive Weight Management Center Taipei Medical University Hospital
